svg.text: Causal Layered Analysis (CLA)
Four Layers of Reality - From Surface to Deep Structure (Sohail Inayatullah, 1998)
Increasing Depth
1. LITANY
Surface level - Headlines, official discourse
What: Quantifiable trends, media headlines, official statements, obvious problems
Question: "What is happening?"
Example: "Traffic congestion is getting worse" • "Crime rates are rising" • "Test scores declining"
2. SYSTEMIC CAUSES
Social, economic, political systems - Technical analysis
What: Economic structures, governance systems, institutional relationships, data patterns
Question: "What are the systemic causes behind the litany?"
Example: "Urban sprawl + car-centric planning" • "Inequality + weak social services" • "Standardized testing regime"
3. WORLDVIEW / DISCOURSE
Deeper assumptions - How we frame problems
What: Ideologies, cultural narratives, epistemic frameworks, what counts as "progress"
Question: "What worldview makes this system seem natural or inevitable?"
Example: "Mobility = individual car ownership" • "Safety through punishment" • "Intelligence = test performance"
4. MYTH / METAPHOR
Deepest level - Unconscious archetypes and images
What: Deep cultural stories, emotional symbols, archetypal narratives, "felt" truths
Question: "What deep story or metaphor holds this worldview in place?"
Example: "Freedom = open road" • "Order vs. chaos battle" • "Meritocracy ladder to climb"
Transformative Futures Work:
Surface-level interventions (litany) rarely create lasting change. Shifting myths/metaphors enables new worldviews, which enable new systems.
